addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

16 N
o
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
D. Casimirs
l
res
to divers of
e
States
./

page.lettertext:
fol.205r
May it please yo
r
good L. sins I sent yo
w
my last
e 11 of this moneth, there is a Ger-
man come hither, under coulo
r
of other buisnes:
but hath brought certaine letters of credence from
D. Cassimire, of w
ch
one is addressed to
Leoninus
e Chauncelo
r
of
Guelderland,
and one among
us in
e
Councel of state
, an other to
Barne-
velt
, and a third to
Cant
e bourghmaster
of
Amsterdame.
That whiche
e messenger
doth deliver by vertue of his credence, is the
advise of Cassimire to
e forsaid parties, that
in any wise they should persuade w
t
this people,
to walke ve ry warely in returning an ans-
wear to
e Empero
rs
Ambassado
rs
, Not to
reject them over peremptorily, nor yet to em-
brace their motions, but so to q
a
lifie their
answear, as both they may seeme desirous
of peace, and yet to trust to no treaty
at
if
is offered by
e Spaniard. That besides
they should urge
e Treaty between her
Ma
tie
and this contrey, and
e neere con-
junction of their cause w
t
e present state
of
France:
for w
ch
they may request of
e
Empero
r
to procure a cessation of armes
of all handes, and in all places, and that
then they could be willing, to come to any
treaty,
at shall tend to a publicke peace.
This message of
e Duke is but a preparative
to a further letter, w
ch
, as
e party doth report,
he is resolved to send hither to
e G
nr
al states.
fol.205v
For as it seemeth he is hardly pressed by
the Empero
r
, to concurre in
e furtherance
of this action w
t
him, and yet his privat
affection to
e state of these contreis doth
move him to be carefull, that they should
not be entrapped. Because his other
letter to
e states in general is expected
every day, there is no answear yet resol-
ved to be given to this messenger. How-
beit esteeming that yo
r
L. woul be wil-
lingly informed, howe every thing doth
passe by
e Spaniardes procurement, I thought
it also requisit to signifie of this writing
of Cassimire hither.
And so I take my
humble leave. From
e Hage.
N
o
16 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
